awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: SCH: Novel User Interfaces for Reporting Personal Health Data to Lay Individuals
awd_abstract_narration:
CRII: Novel User Interfaces for Reporting Personal Health Data to Lay Individuals 

Advances in computing technology now offer individuals unprecedented ways to access personal health data. Such data will reach people in fluctuating emotional states and might deliver information that has life-altering implications. Significant gaps exist in our understanding of how computing systems can expertly report these data to laypeople. This CRII project will align the design of electronic data reporting tools with expert communication strategies and the needs of lay individuals, in the context of oncology care. These tools will be designed to supplement, not replace, individuals' communication with their caregivers. The project will enable the construction of a rich set of data related to communicating personal health information throughout oncological care. After encoding and analyzing the data collected, results of the analysis will be used to formulate design guidelines for interaction techniques and graphical techniques to convey personal health data in a user interface. We expect that the resulting tools will aid cancer patients in managing and acting on personal health data related to cancer diagnosis, treatment and prolonged remission. In addition to the oncology setting, results of the proposed studies should prove beneficial in chronic illness management, particularly for illnesses in which patient engagement with their health data is critical in achieving positive health outcomes. 

This research focuses on assembling a rich set of quantitative and qualitative data to formally characterize both the technical complexity and emotional sensitivity of clinical data types common to oncology care. These data will be used to define, in subsequent research, the sets of variables, dependencies and structural features of computational models to make possible the development of automated approaches to conveying clinically-relevant health data to lay end users. Studies will be conducted in clinical field sites with oncologists and their patients, using a combination of ethnographic methods and surveys. Data collected through these methods will be iteratively coded and analyzed using descriptive, thematic analyses employing a combination of inductive and deductive approaches. Analyses of these data will uncover specific design guidelines for computing tools that convey personal health data to lay individuals in oncology care. A preliminary design based on these guidelines will be developed and iteratively refined based on input from oncology patients, oncologists, and patient-clinician communication researchers. The resulting design will be embodied in a prototype containing interaction techniques and graphical and linguistic framing techniques that demonstrate expert capability in the presentation of clinically-relevant health data. The prototype system will select framings of example data and demonstrate the interaction and presentation techniques designed. Pilot tests of the prototype will be conducted with a subset of the clinicians recruited in earlier phases of the project as well as individuals with prior experience managing chronic illness, recruited at the study site.

por.por_cntn:
This research project focused on how computing tools can communicate personal health information to adolescents with complex chronic illnesses (e.g., adolescents with cancer). The research proceeded in two phases. First, the research examined how communication happens now in pediatric oncology care--including in-person family communication with doctors in the Atlanta area, as well as electronic communication through online patient portals. In the second phase, the research investigated how interactive tools can be designed to report lay-friendly explanations about electronic health information to adolescents and their parents in ways that they find useful, during oncology care.

The first phase involved collecting a large set of data, by conducting observations, interviews, and surveys with patients, their family members, and their doctors. To complement these data, the research also conducted large-scale data analyses of how patients and their parents used information technology to assess status and progress of the patient's health, and to communicate about the patient's health status.

The research conducted in the first phase resulted in several outcomes. We learned that adolescent patients faced particular communication challenges during oncology care that do not befall other types of age groups. For example, adolescent patients faced challenges concerning: 1) the limited ways currently available for teens to participate in their clinical care, 2) communicating emotionally-sensitive information, and 3) managing physical and emotional responses to symptoms and treatment side effects.

These findings about in-person communication and patient engagement in clinical care were published, and more can be read about them here:

1. Matthew Hong, Lauren Wilcox, Daniel Machado, Thomas Olson, Stephen Simoneaux (2016). Care Partnerships: Toward Technology to Support Teens' Participation in their Health Care. Proc. ACM CHI '16, The 2016 annual conference on Human Factors in Computing. May 2016. 5337-5349.  DOI: 10.1145/2858036.2858508

We also learned, through analyses of usage logs of patient and parent interactions with online electronic health record technology, that patients and their parents had different views about the role of the technology for care communication and health management, and different attitudes about its impact on the patient’s ability to manage care. For example, both groups found the use of electronic health records to improve patient–parent coordination of care activities, communication around hospital encounters, and support for transitioning to adult care. However, some parents had concerns about certain diagnostic test results being made available to their children.

These findings about how adolescent patients and their parents used online electronic health record technology were published, and more can be read about them here:

2. Matthew Hong, Lauren Wilcox, Clayton Feustel, Karen Wasilewski-Masker, Thomas Olson, Stephen Simoneaux (2016). Adolescent and Caregiver Use of a Tethered Personal Health Record System. Proc. American Medical Informatics Association (AMIA) Annual Symposium, Nov 2016, Chicago, IL, USA. 628-637, PMCID: PMC5333234

These findings led to design goals for computing systems that support teenage adolescent patients in partnering in their care, and highlighted the need to focus on frequently-used patient data, including diagnostic radiology reports. We found that diagnostic radiology reports are increasingly being made available to patients and their family members. However, these reports are not typically comprehensible to lay recipients, impeding effective communication about report findings.

In the second phase of the research, we analyzed over 200,000 pediatric radiology reports and almost 1000 patient questions about radiology exams and report content, to design radiology report software with tools to support patient–clinician communication about the content of the report. Our software includes tools to see lay-friendly versions of report text, and visual illustrations that supplement the explanations and place report content in the context of an anatomical figure. We ran a clinical pilot study with 14 pediatric patients, their parents and clinicians, to test our software with each patient’s current CT or MRI report. When each of these groups used the software, they reported improvements in patient understanding of their radiology results, and high satisfaction with clinical communication.  

These findings were published and they are described in more detail in:
3. Matthew Hong, Clayton Feustel, Meeshu Agnihori, Max Silverman, Stephen Simoneaux, Lauren Wilcox (2017). Supporting Families in Reviewing and Communicating about Radiology Imaging Studies. Proc. ACM CHI '17, The 2017 annual conf on Human Factors in Computing, 5245-5256. DOI: 10.1145/3025453.3025754

Finally, the research investigated how to incorporate elements of game design when designing interactive user interfaces for personal health applications. It did so through a study with experts in game design, health behavior, and "Games for Health". The findings from this research are published and can be found at:

4. Christina Kelley, Lauren Wilcox, Wendy Ng, Jade Schiffer, Jessica Hammer. Proc. ACM DIS '17,  Design Features in Games for Health: Disciplinary and Interdisciplinary Expert Perspectives. The 2017 Conf on Designing Interactive Systems. June 2017, Edinburgh, UK, 69–81. c1. PMID: 28868523

In addition to the research outcomes stated above, the grant contributed to the training and professional development of two PhD students, four MS students, and two undergraduate students.
